θε-.description: Words relating to God and the divine nature, fundamental to Christian theology

ἁγ-.description: Words expressing holiness, sanctification, and separation for divine purposes
ἁγ-.etymology: Related to ἅγνος (pure, chaste), expressing separation from the profane

πατερ-.description: Family and paternal relationships, both earthly and heavenly fatherhood
πατερ-.etymology: From Proto-Indo-European *ph₂tḗr, cognate with Latin pater

υἱ-.description: Son-ship and filial relationships, central to Christological terminology
υἱ-.etymology: Ancient Greek root for male offspring and divine sonship

πνευματ-.description: Spirit, breath, wind, and spiritual matters - central to pneumatology
πνευματ-.etymology: From πνέω (to blow, breathe), related to Latin spiritus

κυρι-.description: Authority, lordship, dominion - key title for Christ in the New Testament
κυρι-.etymology: From κῦρος (power, authority), related to κυριεύω

ἐλε-.description: Mercy, compassion, and divine grace - fundamental to liturgical prayer
ἐλε-.etymology: Related to ἐλαιος (olive oil), symbolizing healing and mercy

δοξ-.description: Glory, honor, divine majesty, and the visible manifestation of God's presence
δοξ-.etymology: From δοκέω (to seem, appear), relating to divine appearance

βασιλ-.description: Kingship, royal power, and divine kingdom - central to Gospel proclamation
βασιλ-.etymology: Possibly from a pre-Greek substrate, meaning 'king, ruler'

οὐραν-.description: Heavenly and celestial concepts, the dwelling place of God
οὐραν-.etymology: Related to Hittite *h₂wers- (to rain), the dome of the sky

ἁμαρτ-.description: Sin, error, and missing the divine mark - central to soteriology
ἁμαρτ-.etymology: From ἀ- (not) + μαρτάνω (to hit the mark), literally 'missing the target'

ψυχ-.description: Soul, life force, human essence, and the breath of life
ψυχ-.etymology: From ψύχω (to blow, cool), the breath that gives life

ζω-.description: Life, vitality, living existence - both biological and spiritual life

ἀληθ-.description: Truth, reality, divine revelation - that which is not hidden

ἀγαπ-.description: Divine love, spiritual affection, sacrificial love as distinct from eros
ἀγαπ-.etymology: Possibly from ἄγαν (very much) + root expressing affection

πιστ-.description: Faith, trust, belief, and faithful commitment
πιστ-.etymology: From πείθω (to persuade), expressing confidence and trust

σωζ-.description: Salvation, deliverance, preservation from danger or destruction
σωζ-.etymology: From σῶς (safe, sound), expressing wholeness and safety

ἐρχ-.description: Movement, coming, going - often describing divine advent or human approach to God
ἐρχ-.etymology: Ancient Greek root for movement and traveling

γεν-.description: Becoming, birth, generation, and coming into existence
γεν-.etymology: From Proto-Indo-European *ǵenh₁- meaning 'to beget, give birth'

δο-.description: Giving, granting, bestowing - often describing divine gifts

ἀφι-.description: Sending away, releasing, forgiving - central to concepts of divine mercy
ἀφι-.etymology: From ἀπό (away from) + ἵημι (to send), sending away

αἰων-.description: Age, eternity, forever - temporal and eternal dimensions
αἰων-.etymology: Related to αἰεί (always), expressing perpetual time
